message: I wish everyone in the Hudson Valley a Happy New Year! Please be sure to celebrate the holiday responsibly.

This is not about politics - this is about ethics. I believe that folks in Congress should be held to the same standards as the people we represent. Ordinary citizens wouldn't be allowed to investigate an allegation against themselves and neither should Congress.   I will strongly oppose any legislation which would eliminate the independent power of the Office of Congressional Ethics.

Swearing in today with the family.   “I Sean Patrick Maloney do solemnly swear that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office on which I am about to enter. So help me god.”   It will be my honor to continue serving the great people of the Hudson Valley in the United States House of Representatives.
Thanks to all of the first responders on the scene of the @LIRR crash. Dozens injured, we’re lucky it appears no one was killed.

It is an honor to serve our Hudson Valley veterans, businesses and hardworking families for another two years – working together we will continue fighting to create good paying jobs, protect Social Security and Medicare, and invest in our local infrastructure. In the last four years I built a record of results, passing 25 pieces of legislation into law and returning $6.3 million to local taxpayers, and I can’t wait to continue getting things done for my neighbors in the Hudson Valley and across New York.

I will fight tooth and nail against efforts to cut corners or balance the budget on the backs of seniors who did everything right. Transparency in government is essential for a healthy democracy – and has been the norm for every president for decades. I have to disclose my finances – as do my colleagues in both Houses of Congress – as well as all of the president-elect’s nominees. I cosponsored the Presidential Tax Transparency Act because I think the public has a right to know where the president has money invested – and if he or she pays taxes. This isn’t about politics, it’s about ethics.

Seven years ago today the Supreme Court made one of the worst decisions in history. The Citizens United ruling allows corporations to pour millions of dollars of secret dark money into races throughout the country. Our democracy needs transparent elections.
I support the landmark decision in Roe v. Wade because I support a woman’s right to choose. Personal, medical decisions should be up to a woman and her doctor – not Washington politicians. Period.

Her confirmation hearings were the most embarrassing I’ve ever seen and prove she didn’t even google education policy before setting foot in the Senate. I will keep my eye on Secretary DeVos and the rest of the administration to make sure all our kids have the chance to get a great education.

I still count the 2014 Farm Bill as one of the most important things I’ve done in Congress. Our farmers create thousands of jobs and bring millions to the Hudson Valley economy – not to mention feed our country.  I was able to include legislation to support our specialty crop growers, require the Department of Ag to work with our farmers in the Black Dirt Region, prioritize Lyme Disease research,  help our organic farmers, and improve distribution of locally grown food. It was a huge win for the Hudson Valley – and I look forward to continuing my work on behalf of our ag producers.

Being poor is not a crime. I introduced this bill to make sure that people aren’t sent to jail because they can’t afford a fancy high power attorney and need a public defender. The public defender system is swamped with cases, so people often don’t get the defense that the Constitution promises – my bill would fix that.

People keep talking about vouchers and reducing benefits and raising the retirement age – not on my watch. I won’t support legislation that would pull the rug out from seniors who did everything right in life. If you worked and paid into the system, you deserve to get your pay out when you retire.

It has been my honor to help over 800 vets cut through red tape at the VA and pass eight bills to benefit our vets community. We owe it to them.

A budget blueprint he released calls for closing the Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS) Office – the office that has provided investments to hire 130,000 police officers nationwide. I joined Middletown Mayor Joe DeStefano and Acting Police Chief John Ewanciw to call on the President to reconsider this dangerous move.

On March 7, 1965, a group of African Americans set out across the Edmund Pettus Bridge to draw attention to violations of their Constitutional right to vote and to hold their Governor accountable for violence and segregation. Demonstrators were beaten, but they eventually won – and the Voting Rights Act was passed. It was an honor for me and my family to stand with Civil Rights Hero John Lewis on the very same bridge fifty years later – and it’s a constant reminder of the work left to be done.
